PackVFL: Efficient HE Packing for Vertical Federated Learning

Liu Yang Hong Kong University of Science and TechnologyHong KongChina lyangau@cse.ust.hk ,  Shuowei Cai Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (Guangzhou)GuangzhouChina scaiak@connect.hkust-gz.edu.cn ,  Di Chai Hong Kong University of Science and TechnologyHong KongChina dchai@cse.ust.hk ,  Junxue Zhang ,  Han Tian ,  Yilun Jin Hong Kong University of Science and TechnologyHong KongChina jzhangcs.htianab.yilun.jin@connect.ust.hk ,  Kun Guo Fuzhou UniversityFuzhouChina gukn@fzu.edu.cn ,  Kai Chen  and  Qiang Yang Hong Kong University of Science and TechnologyHong KongChina kaichen.qyang@cse.ust.hk
Abstract.

As an essential tool of secure distributed machine learning, vertical federated learning (VFL) based on homomorphic encryption (HE) suffers from severe efficiency problems due to data inflation and time-consuming operations. To this core, we propose PackVFL, an efficient VFL framework based on packed HE (PackedHE), to accelerate the existing HE-based VFL algorithms. PackVFL packs multiple cleartexts into one ciphertext and supports single-instruction-multiple-data (SIMD)-style parallelism. We focus on designing a high-performant matrix multiplication (MatMult) method since it takes up most of the ciphertext computation time in HE-based VFL. Besides, devising the MatMult method is also challenging for PackedHE because a slight difference in the packing way could predominantly affect its computation and communication costs. Without domain-specific design, directly applying SOTA MatMult methods is hard to achieve optimal.

Therefore, we make a three-fold design: 1) we systematically explore the current design space of MatMult and quantify the complexity of existing approaches to provide guidance; 2) we propose a hybrid MatMult method according to the unique characteristics of VFL; 3) we adaptively apply our hybrid method in representative VFL algorithms, leveraging distinctive algorithmic properties to further improve efficiency. As the batch size, feature dimension and model size of VFL scale up to large sizes, PackVFL consistently delivers enhanced performance. Empirically, PackVFL propels existing VFL algorithms to new heights, achieving up to a 51.52×\times end-to-end speedup. This represents a substantial 34.51×\times greater speedup compared to the direct application of SOTA MatMult methods.

1. Introduction

Vertical federated learning (VFL) (Yang et al., 2019b; Yang et al., 2023) based on homomorphic encryption (HE) (Acar et al., 2018) gradually becomes a trend of secure distributed machine learning among data silos (McMahan et al., 2021; Chen et al., 2021b; Pfitzner et al., 2021; Fink et al., 2021). VFL solves the problem: multiple data owners, e.g., companies or institutions, hold vertically partitioned data. They want to collaboratively train models without leaking the original data. During the process of HE-based VFL, raw data are maintained locally. Only intermediate results for calculating model updates are encrypted by HE (Zhu et al., 2019) and exchanged among parties for further cryptographic computation. HE-based VFL is crucial for legally enriching ML features in both academia and industry.

However, state-of-the-art (SOTA) HE-based VFL algorithms (Yang et al., 2019b; Chen et al., 2021b; Zhang and Zhu, 2020; Cheng et al., 2021) suffer from severe efficiency issues, which hinder VFL’s wider application. On the one hand, their adopted HE methods, e.g., Paillier (Paillier, 1999), largely inflate data size to more than 40×\times (Zhang et al., 2020), leading to communication and memory overheads. On the other hand, the adopted HE methods introduce time-consuming cryptographic operations, dominating the training process. We dig into these operations and find that matrix multiplication (MatMult) is the efficiency bottleneck. Taking the VFL-LinR algorithm (Yang et al., 2019b) as an example, MatMult gradually occupies the majority of cryptographic computation time, up to 99.23%, shown in Tab. 1.

Our Contribution. In this paper, we propose PackVFL, an efficient VFL framework to accelerate the existing HE-based VFL algorithms. In detail, PackVFL is based on packed homomorphic encryption (PackedHE) (Brakerski et al., 2013; Brakerski et al., 2014; Fan and Vercauteren, 2012; Cheon et al., 2017) and packs multiple cleartexts into one ciphertext to alleviate the data inflation problem and support parallel computation, i.e., single-instruction-multiple-data (SIMD), over the packed values. More specifically, we focus on devising a high-performant MatMult method tailored for the VFL scenario. Empirically, we show the superiority of PackVFL, with 33.30×\times, 3.22×\times, 51.52×\times speedup over SOTA HE-based VFL algorithms, i.e., VFL-LinR (Yang et al., 2019b), CAESAR (Chen et al., 2021b), VFL-NN (Zhang and Zhu, 2020) algorithms, respectively, in the end-to-end experiment.

1.1. Our Techniques

As the most time-consuming cryptographic operation in HE-based VFL, MatMult is also the design challenge of PackVFL. When PackedHE MatMult is adopted in the VFL scenario, the way of packing cleartexts primarily affects its computation and communication cost. Without domain-specific design, MatMult still seriously slows down the training process. For instance, we utilize the naive PackedHE MatMult method (Halevi and Shoup, 2014) in VFL-LinR and find it even slower than Paillier with small batch size, e.g., 32, as shown in Tab. 1. The reason is the naive (row-order) method contains too many rotation operations (Halevi and Shoup, 2014), causing a significant computation overhead. We provide a detailed explanation in §3.

Besides, SOTA PackedHE MatMult methods proposed by (Juvekar et al., 2018; Mishra et al., 2020; Zhang et al., 2021; Huang et al., 2022b; Hao et al., 2022) are also sub-optimal for the VFL scenario without domain specific designs. Among them, the methods of GAZELLE (Juvekar et al., 2018), DELPHI (Mishra et al., 2020) and GALA (Zhang et al., 2021) cause extra computation overheads, while the methods of Cheetah (Huang et al., 2022b) and Iron (Hao et al., 2022) result in extensive communication overheads in VFL. Based on this fact, we raise the question: Can we design a PackedHE MatMult method that is ideally tailored for the current HE-based VFL algorithms? As we will show, the answer is yes. Our new MatMult method outperforms SOTA PackedHE MatMult methods theoretically in §4 and empirically in §7.

1.1.1. Systematical Exploration of Design Space.

As one of the design emphases of PackedHE, the MatMult method has been continuously undergoing updates and iterations (Juvekar et al., 2018; Mishra et al., 2020; Zhang et al., 2021; Huang et al., 2022b; Hao et al., 2022; Halevi and Shoup, 2014). Therefore, we provide a comprehensive analysis of the current design space and quantify the complexity of existing approaches to guide our design of PackVFL in §3. Based on the main idea of packing cleartexts, we divide them into slot packing methods (Juvekar et al., 2018; Mishra et al., 2020; Zhang et al., 2021; Sav et al., 2021; Xu et al., 2022; Halevi and Shoup, 2014) and coefficient packing methods (Huang et al., 2022b; Hao et al., 2022). Taking the MatMult between cleartext matrix 𝑿𝑿\bm{X} and ciphertext vector ⟦𝒚⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝒚\llbracket\bm{y}\rrbracket as as example, we compare their methodologies. Slot packing methods follow the standard encoding procedure of PackedHE. It arranges which cleartexts of 𝑿𝑿\bm{X} are encoded together into a plaintext and their order. On the contrary, coefficient packing methods deviate from the standard procedure and directly map the cleartexts of 𝑿𝑿\bm{X} to specific coefficients of plaintext. The slot and coefficient packing methods have pros and cons considering computation and communication complexities. Thus, the challenge lies in selecting the appropriate design path and further driving domain-specific innovations.

1.1.2. MatMult Design for VFL Characteristics.

To overcome the above challenge, we summarize three characteristics of the VFL’s required MatMult operation and design a hybrid MatMult method correspondingly in §4. The first characteristic is that the two operands of VFL MatMult are held by geo-distributed parties. One operand is encrypted by one party and transmitted to another for MatMult computation. After that, the resulting ciphertext is sent back. Through theoretical and empirical analyses of computation and communication costs, we opt for the slot packing concept. As a result, we propose PackVFL’s diagonal method as the core component of our hybrid approach, detailed in §4.1. The second characteristic is wide-range operand size. In VFL, the operand size of MatMult is related to batch size, feature dimension, and model architecture, with a wide range from small to large. Hence, we design delicate input packing and input partitioning techniques to further improve efficiency, correspondingly for the small- and large-operand situation in §4.2. The third characteristic is that the MatMult result is passively decrypted after transmission to the party with secret key. No extra operation is conducted. Due to this characteristic, we design the lazy rotate-and-sum (RaS) mechanism as the last component of our hybrid method to eliminate the remaining time-consuming ciphertext operation (rotation (Halevi and Shoup, 2014)) contained at the end of MatMult in §4.3.

Till now, our hybrid method has already shown its superiority over SOTA PackedHE MatMult methods, discussed in §4. For the computation comparison in §7.2, our hybrid method performs the best with the highest 846×\times and 1.24×\times speedup over the naive method (Halevi and Shoup, 2014) and the SOTA method of GALA (Zhang et al., 2021), respectively.

1.1.3. Adaption Design to SOTA VFL Algorithms.

To further improve the end-to-end training efficiency, we dig into the secure protocols of three representative HE-based VFL algorithms, i.e., VFL-LinR (Yang et al., 2019b), CAESAR (Chen et al., 2021b), VFL-NN (Zhang and Zhu, 2020) 111Our focus on VFL-LinR, CAESAR, and VFL-NN is due to their foundational status and widespread recognition in HE-based VFL applications (Yang et al., 2023). for illustration, and adaptively apply our MatMult method in them with three extra delicate mechanisms, leveraging their distinctive algorithmic properties, in §5. More detailedly, we design the multiplication level reduction mechanism, which modifies CAESAR’s original computation process to use more efficient PackedHE parameters in §5.2. To make the lazy RaS component of our hybrid method feasible with this modification, we also design the cleartext inverse RaS mechanism. In §5.3, focusing on VFL-NN, we encounter a new MatMult scenario between matrices 𝑿⟦𝒀⟧\bm{X}\llbracket\bm{Y}\rrbracket. Rather than adhering to the conventional approach to diagonally encode the cleartext matrix 𝑿𝑿\bm{X}, we change our mind to diagonally encode the ciphertext matrix ⟦𝒀⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝒀\llbracket\bm{Y}\rrbracket, significantly enhancing efficiency. Moreover, we develop the transposed matrices’ diagonal conversion mechanism, enabling conversion between two encrypted transposed matrices, further halving the communication cost.

Together with the adaption optimization, PackVFL has more speedup over VFL-LinR (Yang et al., 2019b), CAESAR (Chen et al., 2021b) and VFL-NN (Zhang and Zhu, 2020) than the SOTA method of GALA by 9.02×\times, 0.91×\times and 33.1×\times respectively. More details are shown in §7.1. Besisdes, we also show that none of our designs harms the accuracy of VFL algorithms in §7.1.

1.1.4. PackVFL’s Innovations and New Insights.

As a cross-disciplinary effort bridging federated learning (FL) and cryptography, PackVFL makes significant contributions to both fields. For the FL community, PackVFL stands as one of the pioneering works to demonstrate the superiority of PackedHE over Paillier for VFL. We provide a counter-intuitive result that PackedHE is more suitable for VFL with our elaborate design. The VFL’s community has the intuition that PackedHE is much slower than Paillier since PackedHE is more complicated and supports more cryptographic operations. We are the first to devise an efficient MatMult method tailored to meet VFL’s specific requirements, showcasing its effectiveness across various VFL algorithms.

For the cryptography community, our proposed MatMult method exhibits potential advantages over state-of-the-art slot packing approaches, not only in VFL but also in other related domains such as secure model inference (Mann et al., 2022). Additionally, we extend the MatMult scenario from matrix-vector 𝑿⟦𝒚⟧\bm{X}\llbracket\bm{y}\rrbracket to matrix-matrix 𝑿⟦𝒀⟧\bm{X}\llbracket\bm{Y}\rrbracket and design PackedHE techniques of the cleartext inverse RaS and transposed matrices’ diagonal conversion, which is unprecedented in earlier works.

1.2. Other Related Work

Several existing works (Sav et al., 2021; Xu et al., 2022; Ou et al., 2020; Jin et al., 2022; Lu et al., 2023; Wang et al., 2023) also utilize PackedHE to construct federated algorithms. However, (Ou et al., 2020; Wang et al., 2023) provide no design details about MatMult. (Jin et al., 2022; Lu et al., 2023) designed multiplication between ciphertext vectors, which differs from our setting. (Sav et al., 2021; Xu et al., 2022) involve SOTA PackedHE MatMult designs. But, their target MatMult operation is a single-party continuous MatMult operation without interaction, which is different from the requirements VFL. Therefore, they cannot be adopted in the VFL scenario. Besides, PackedHE hardware acceleration works, e.g., (Zhang et al., 2022; Samardzic et al., 2021; Su et al., 2020), can also be utilized to improve our performance further since PackVFL is a high-level application of PackedHE and changes no basic cryptographic operations.

2. Background and Preliminaries

2.1. Vertical Federated Learning

Vertical federated learning (VFL) (Yang et al., 2019b; Yang et al., 2023) takes a significant part of cross-silo distributed machine learning, whose participants are business companies (McMahan et al., 2021; Fink et al., 2021). Companies usually maintain different portraits for common users, i.e., vertical data partition (Chen et al., 2021b). VFL enables secure model training over these abundant distributed features to achieve better prediction accuracy, complying with laws and regulations such as GDPR 222GDPR is a regulation in EU law on data protection and privacy in the European Union and the European Economic Area. https://gdpr.eu/.. Therefore, VFL holds substantial real-world importance. For example, (Errounda and Liu, 2022) utilized VFL to help prevent COVID-19 (Ilin et al., 2021).

2.1.1. HE-based VFL is a Widely-Adopted and Practical Solution.

During the VFL training process, intermediate results instead of original data are exchanged among parties. To further protect intermediate results from disclosing privacy (Zhu et al., 2019), VFL adopts various privacy-preserving methods, e.g., differential privacy (DP) (Dwork et al., 2014), secret sharing (SS) (Beimel, 2011), and homomorphic encryption (HE) (Acar et al., 2018). HE-based VFL (Yang et al., 2019b; Cheng et al., 2021; Chen et al., 2021b; Zhang and Zhu, 2020; Cai et al., 2022a) turns out to be a practical solution since DP-based VFL (Xu et al., 2019) and SS-based VFL (Mohassel and Zhang, 2017; Mohassel and Rindal, 2018) suffer from either severe accuracy loss (Yang et al., 2023) 333DP is more adept at defending the adversarial attacks (Lecuyer et al., 2019) and membership attacks (Bernau et al., 2021), which are orthogonal to the privacy leakage during the training process. or large communication overhead (Chen et al., 2021b). HE could provide the homomorphism between calculation over ciphertext and calculation over cleartext. HE-based VFL encrypts the transmitted messages, conducts computations on the received ciphertext, and decrypts the results to update the model.

Fig. 1 illustrates a two-party HE-based VFL scenario. Party A (PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A}) owns a private dataset 𝒟A=(ℐA,𝑭A)subscript𝒟𝐴subscriptℐ𝐴subscript𝑭𝐴\mathcal{D}_{A}=(\mathcal{I}_{A},~{}\bm{F}_{A}), where ℐℐ\mathcal{I} stands for the sample identifiers and 𝑭Asubscript𝑭𝐴\bm{F}_{A} represents the features. Party B (PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B}) holds 𝒟B=(ℐB,𝑭B,𝒍B)subscript𝒟𝐵subscriptℐ𝐵subscript𝑭𝐵subscript𝒍𝐵\mathcal{D}_{B}=(\mathcal{I}_{B},~{}\bm{F}_{B},~{}\bm{l}_{B}), where 𝒍Bsubscript𝒍𝐵\bm{l}_{B} means labels. The first step of VFL is entity alignment, e.g., private set intersection (PSI) (Liang and Chawathe, 2004), to securely find the samples with common identifiers between two parties and use them as training data. The second step is federated training. At each iteration, PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} and PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} first conduct cleartext calculation over local data, then exchange encrypted ciphertext for multiplication, e.g., matrix multiplication (MatMult), addition, and decrypt gradients to update model weights 𝑾A,𝑾Bsubscript𝑾𝐴subscript𝑾𝐵\bm{W}_{A},\bm{W}_{B}.

2.1.2. Paillier’s Batching is Limited for VFL.

Paillier (Acar et al., 2018) is VFL’s most commonly adopted HE approach. It inflates data size and introduces time-consuming operations due to limited support for SIMD operations. Although Paillier’s batching techniques (Zhang et al., 2020; Jiang et al., 2021) tried to fill several cleartexts into one ciphertext, they do not support the MatMult operation. As shown in Tab. 1, MatMult dominates the cryptographic operations of the VFL training process with up to 99.23% proportion. Therefore, Paillier’s batching techniques cannot be utilized in VFL. Besides, Paillier is based on the decisional composite residuosity assumption, which is vulnerable to post-quantum attacks (Shor, 1999). Yet, Paillier remains the predominant HE technique in VFL.

2.2. Packed Homomorphic Encryption

Packed homomorphic encryption (PackedHE), e.g., BGV (Brakerski et al., 2014), BFV (Fan and Vercauteren, 2012), CKKS (Cheon et al., 2017), and multiparty BFV (Mouchet et al., 2020), naturally supports more functional and powerful SIMD-style batching than Paillier. As shown in Fig. 1, PackedHE with the naive MatMult method has already outperformed Paillier as the number of encrypted cleartexts increases. Moreover, PackedHE is based on a variant of learning with errors (LWE), i.e., ring LWE (RLWE) (Lyubashevsky et al., 2013), which is quantum-resilient (Nejatollahi et al., 2019).

LWE encrypts a cleartext vector 𝒙∈ℤqN𝒙subscriptsuperscriptℤ𝑁𝑞\bm{x}\in\mathbb{Z}^{N}_{q} into a ciphertext ⟦𝒙⟧=(𝒄0,𝒄1)=(𝒙−𝑨𝒔+𝒆,𝑨)\llbracket\bm{x}\rrbracket=(\bm{c}_{0},\bm{c}_{1})=(\bm{x}-\bm{A}\bm{s}+\bm{e},\bm{A}), where N𝑁N stands for the vector length, q𝑞q is the cleartext modulus (large prime number), 𝑨∈ℤqN×N𝑨subscriptsuperscriptℤ𝑁𝑁𝑞\bm{A}\in\mathbb{Z}^{N\times N}_{q} is uniformly sampled, 𝒔∈ℤqN𝒔subscriptsuperscriptℤ𝑁𝑞\bm{s}\in\mathbb{Z}^{N}_{q} represents the secret key, and 𝒆∈ℤqN𝒆subscriptsuperscriptℤ𝑁𝑞\bm{e}\in\mathbb{Z}^{N}_{q} is small noise to make the problem hard. The decryption can only be conducted with 𝒔𝒔\bm{s}: 𝒄0+𝒄1​𝒔=𝒙−𝑨​𝒔+𝒆+𝑨​𝒔=𝒙+𝒆≈𝒙subscript𝒄0subscript𝒄1𝒔𝒙𝑨𝒔𝒆𝑨𝒔𝒙𝒆𝒙\bm{c}_{0}+\bm{c}_{1}\bm{s}=\bm{x}-\bm{A}\bm{s}+\bm{e}+\bm{A}\bm{s}=\bm{x}+\bm{e}\approx\bm{x}. One disadvantage of LWE is that the size of matrix 𝑨𝑨\bm{A} is quadratic with the vector length N𝑁N, which will cause large communication costs to transmit ciphertext.

PackedHE utilizes RLWE to solve this problem. For a cleartext vector 𝒙∈ℂN/2𝒙subscriptℂ𝑁2\bm{x}\in\mathbb{C}_{N/2}, before encryption, PackedHE encodes it to plaintext, i.e., an integer polynomial x~∈ℤq​[X]/(XN+1)~𝑥subscriptℤ𝑞delimited-[]𝑋superscript𝑋𝑁1\tilde{x}\in\mathbb{Z}_{q}[X]/(X^{N}+1). For example, the standard encoding of CKKS utilizes cyclotomic polynomial to construct a one-to-one mapping between the cleartext vector and plaintext polynomial (Cheon et al., 2017). Then, PackedHE encrypts plaintext x~~𝑥\tilde{x} to ciphertext ⟦𝒙⟧=(c~0,c~1)=(x~−a~s~+e~,a~)\llbracket\bm{x}\rrbracket=(\tilde{c}_{0},\tilde{c}_{1})=(\tilde{x}-\tilde{a}\tilde{s}+\tilde{e},\tilde{a}). Values in the cleartext vector can be regarded to be encoded/encrypted in the corresponding position (slot) of plaintext/ciphertext with the same order. Slot number N′=N/2superscript𝑁′𝑁2N^{\prime}=N/2 refers to how many cleartexts can be encrypted in one RLWE ciphertext. The size of polynomial a~~𝑎\tilde{a} is linear with N𝑁N, which is much more efficient than LWE.

We conclude the basic RLWE operations that will be used in the following sections:

  • ∙∙\bullet

    O1 (Add), which represents slot-wise addition, e.g., ⟦𝒙⟧+⟦𝒚⟧\llbracket\bm{x}\rrbracket+\llbracket\bm{y}\rrbracket = ⟦𝒙+𝒚⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝒙𝒚\llbracket\bm{x}+\bm{y}\rrbracket or 𝒙+⟦𝒚⟧\bm{x}+\llbracket\bm{y}\rrbracket = ⟦𝒙+𝒚⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝒙𝒚\llbracket\bm{x}+\bm{y}\rrbracket;

  • ∙∙\bullet

    O2 (Mult), which represents slot-wise multiplication, e.g., ⟦𝒙⟧×⟦𝒚⟧=⟦𝒙×𝒚⟧\llbracket\bm{x}\rrbracket\times\llbracket\bm{y}\rrbracket=\llbracket\bm{x}\times\bm{y}\rrbracket or 𝒙×⟦𝒚⟧=⟦𝒙×𝒚⟧\bm{x}\times\llbracket\bm{y}\rrbracket=\llbracket\bm{x}\times\bm{y}\rrbracket;

  • ∙∙\bullet

    O3 (Rot), which represents a rotation operation that shifts ciphertext slots in sequence. RotL/R(⟦𝒙⟧,i)\mbox{RotL/R}(\llbracket\bm{x}\rrbracket,i) denotes rotating ⟦𝒙⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝒙\llbracket\bm{x}\rrbracket to the left/right for i𝑖i position. Rotation is the most costly basic RLWE operation, which is more than 10×\times slower than O1 (Add) and O2 (Mult);

  • ∙∙\bullet

    O4 (HstRot), which represents hoisting rotation that is a more efficient optimization to conduct multiple rotation operations over the same ciphertext (Juvekar et al., 2018). HstRotL/R(⟦𝒙⟧,i)\mbox{HstRotL/R}(\llbracket\bm{x}\rrbracket,i) denotes i𝑖i-position left/right HstRot of ⟦𝒙⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝒙\llbracket\bm{x}\rrbracket.

2.2.1. Designing PackedHE MatMult is Non-Trivial.

PackedHE has already achieved good efficiency when conducting basic O1 (Add) and O2 (Mult) operations with SIMD property. However, there exist difficulties when designing a more complicated PackedHE MatMult method (Juvekar et al., 2018). The main reason is that PackedHE needs O3 (Rot) operations to sum values in different slots of ciphertexts. Since matrix multiplication needs a large number of vector inner sum operations, PackedHE MatMult is inclined to be inefficient without proper designs.

3. Systematical Exploration of Design Space

The existing works (Halevi and Shoup, 2014; Juvekar et al., 2018; Mishra et al., 2020; Zhang et al., 2021; Huang et al., 2022b; Hao et al., 2022) have proposed SOTA designs for PackedHE MatMult. Taking the VFL’s MatMult between matrix and vector as an example, we introduce and compare their methods to provide guidance for our design. The VFL’s MatMult is formulated as:

(1) 𝑿A⟦𝒚B⟧=⟦𝑿A𝒚B⟧,\bm{X}_{A}\llbracket\bm{y}_{B}\rrbracket=\llbracket\bm{X}_{A}\bm{y}_{B}\rrbracket,

where 𝑿A∈ℝm×nsubscript𝑿𝐴superscriptℝ𝑚𝑛\bm{X}_{A}\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times n} is held by PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A}, 𝒚B∈ℝn×1subscript𝒚𝐵superscriptℝ𝑛1\bm{y}_{B}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times 1} is held by PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B}. In VFL’s process, PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} encrypts 𝒚Bsubscript𝒚𝐵\bm{y}_{B} as ⟦𝒚B⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝒚𝐵\llbracket\bm{y}_{B}\rrbracket and sends it to PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} for MatMult. The resulting ciphertext is transmitted back to PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} for decryption. 𝑿Asubscript𝑿𝐴\bm{X}_{A} should also be encoded to plaintexts before MatMult.

We mainly divide the existing MatMult methods of (Halevi and Shoup, 2014; Juvekar et al., 2018; Mishra et al., 2020; Zhang et al., 2021; Huang et al., 2022b; Hao et al., 2022) into two categories below and will show their advantages and disadvantages in the following of this section:

  • ∙∙\bullet

    Slot packing methods that follow the standard encoding procedure of PackedHE, decide which cleartexts are encoded together into a plaintext and arrange their order (Halevi and Shoup, 2014; Juvekar et al., 2018; Mishra et al., 2020; Zhang et al., 2021);

  • ∙∙\bullet

    Coefficient packing methods that deviate from the standard procedure and focus on designing novel mapping between cleartexts to specific coefficients of plaintext (Huang et al., 2022b; Hao et al., 2022).

In the following of this paper, we mention GAZELLE (Juvekar et al., 2018), DELPHI (Mishra et al., 2020), GALA (Zhang et al., 2021), Cheetah (Huang et al., 2022b), and Iron (Huang et al., 2022b) to only represent their MatMult methods for simplicity. Since their primary focus is on secure CNN inference, other technical contributions, e.g., secure convolution techniques, are not applicable in our VFL scenario. Besides, we assume that m,n,N𝑚𝑛𝑁m,n,N are both power of two. In the real-world scenario, m,n𝑚𝑛m,n are not always the power of two, we can conduct the padding operation over 𝑿Asubscript𝑿𝐴\bm{X}_{A} and 𝒚Bsubscript𝒚𝐵\bm{y}_{B} with zero (Benaissa et al., 2021). We set m=4,n=2formulae-sequence𝑚4𝑛2m=4,n=2 for demonstration. Matrix 𝑿Asubscript𝑿𝐴\bm{X}_{A} has four rows, i.e., [A0,A1]subscript𝐴0subscript𝐴1[A_{0},A_{1}], [B0,B1]subscript𝐵0subscript𝐵1[B_{0},B_{1}], [C0,C1]subscript𝐶0subscript𝐶1[C_{0},C_{1}], and [D0,D1]subscript𝐷0subscript𝐷1[D_{0},D_{1}], while column-vector 𝒚Bsubscript𝒚𝐵\bm{y}_{B} contains two elements, i.e., M0subscript𝑀0M_{0} and M1subscript𝑀1M_{1}. Aisubscript𝐴𝑖A_{i}, Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i}, and Misubscript𝑀𝑖M_{i} are scalars to illustrate the computation process. Tab. 2 shows both the computation and communication complexity of the involved method. For a clear comparison, we assume N𝑁N is large enough without needing matrix/vector partition.

3.1. Slot Packing

The fundamental idea of slot packing is deciding the encoding logic of the matrix operand (Halevi and Shoup, 2014). Among the choices, row-order and column-order encodings are relatively intuitive. The slot packing methods are illustrated in Fig. 2 with N′=4superscript𝑁′4N^{\prime}=4.

3.1.1. Row-Order (Naive) Method.

The row-order (naive) method (Halevi and Shoup, 2014) is regarded as the most intuitive solution, which is frequently discussed as a baseline in related works (Juvekar et al., 2018; Mishra et al., 2020; Zhang et al., 2021). And we also use the naive method to conduct the motivation experiments in Tab. 1. The efficiency of the naive method is largely slowed down by the required m​log2⁡n+m−1𝑚subscript2𝑛𝑚1m\log_{2}n+m-1 O3 (Rot) operations, shown in Tab. 2. In our experiments, O3 (Rot) consumes around 90% time of the naive method when m=n=128𝑚𝑛128m=n=128.

Shown in Fig. 2, the process of the naive method is: 1) each row of matrix 𝑿Asubscript𝑿𝐴\bm{X}_{A} is encoded to e~isubscript~𝑒𝑖\tilde{e}_{i}, respectively. For example, e~0subscript~𝑒0\tilde{e}_{0} contains [A0,A1,⋅,⋅]subscript𝐴0subscript𝐴1⋅⋅[A_{0},A_{1},~{}\cdot,~{}\cdot], where we make omissions for vacant slots; 2) we multiply each e~isubscript~𝑒𝑖\tilde{e}_{i} with ciphertext ⟦𝒚B⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝒚𝐵\llbracket\bm{y}_{B}\rrbracket; 3) since the values in one ciphertext cannot be directly summed up in PackedHE, we conduct log2⁡nsubscript2𝑛\log_{2}n Rotation-and-Sum (RaS) for each resulting ciphertext, which shifts the ciphertext for some specific position, i.e., O3 (Rot), and adds the new ciphertext back to the old one. For instance, we conduct RotL(⟦[A0M0,A1M1,⋅,⋅]⟧,1)\mbox{RotL}(\llbracket[A_{0}M_{0},A_{1}M_{1},\cdot,\cdot]\rrbracket,1), obtain ⟦[A1​M1,A0​M0,⋅,⋅]⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝐴1subscript𝑀1subscript𝐴0subscript𝑀0⋅⋅\llbracket[A_{1}M_{1},A_{0}M_{0},\cdot,\cdot]\rrbracket and conduct ⟦[A0M0,A1M1,⋅,⋅]⟧+⟦[A1M1,A0M0,⋅,⋅]⟧\llbracket[A_{0}M_{0},A_{1}M_{1},\cdot,\cdot]\rrbracket+\llbracket[A_{1}M_{1},A_{0}M_{0},\cdot,\cdot]\rrbracket. After m​log2⁡n𝑚subscript2𝑛m\log_{2}n RaS containing m​log2⁡n𝑚subscript2𝑛m\log_{2}n O3 (Rot), we get the result of each row’s dot product with ⟦𝒚B⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝒚𝐵\llbracket\bm{y}_{B}\rrbracket at the first slot; 4) we want to obtain the expected result of MatMult in one ciphertext. To achieve this goal, we multiply each resulting ciphertext of the previous step with a cleartext indicator vector, which is only set to one at the first position and zero at other positions. Finally, we conduct extra m−1𝑚1m-1 O3 (Rot) to further adjust the maintained values to appropriate slots and sum them together.

3.1.2. Column-Order Method.

The column-order method (Halevi and Shoup, 2014) is less studied, even though owning a small computation complexity with no O3 (Rot) operations, shown in Tab. 2. However, it has a nearly n×n\times communication complexity than naive method. Column-order method follows an opposite logic to the naive method. Fig. 2 shows its process: 1) each column of matrix 𝑿Asubscript𝑿𝐴\bm{X}_{A} is encoded into e~isubscript~𝑒𝑖\tilde{e}_{i}. e~0subscript~𝑒0\tilde{e}_{0} contains [A0,B0,C0,D0]subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵0subscript𝐶0subscript𝐷0[A_{0},B_{0},C_{0},D_{0}] and e~1subscript~𝑒1\tilde{e}_{1} contains [A1,B1,C1,D1]subscript𝐴1subscript𝐵1subscript𝐶1subscript𝐷1[A_{1},B_{1},C_{1},D_{1}]; 2) the vector 𝒚𝒚\bm{y} is encoded and encrypted to n=2𝑛2n=2 ciphertexts. Each one separately replicates the corresponding element of 𝒚Bsubscript𝒚𝐵\bm{y}_{B}, i.e., ⟦[M0,M0,M0,M0]⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝑀0subscript𝑀0subscript𝑀0subscript𝑀0\llbracket[M_{0},M_{0},M_{0},M_{0}]\rrbracket and ⟦[M1,M1,M1,M1]⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝑀1subscript𝑀1subscript𝑀1subscript𝑀1\llbracket[M_{1},M_{1},M_{1},M_{1}]\rrbracket. These n𝑛n RLWE-ciphertexts are sent from PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} to PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A}, causing large communication overhead. By contrast, the naive method only transmits one RLWE-ciphertext (ct); 3) slot-wise multiplication is conducted for each e~isubscript~𝑒𝑖\tilde{e}_{i} and corresponding ciphertext from PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B}; 4) PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} performs slot-wise addition for results of the previous step and sends the obtained one RLWE-ct back to PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B}.

3.1.3. GALA’s Diagonal Method.

Diagonal methods (Mishra et al., 2020; Juvekar et al., 2018; Zhang et al., 2021) are popular for slot packing. Their main idea is to place the values required to be added in the same slot of different ciphertexts to reduce the needed O3 (Rot). DELPHI (Mishra et al., 2020) is a GAZELLE (Juvekar et al., 2018) variant, assuming the input matrix of MatMult can be known in advance and moving part of the computation to the preprocessing phase. Since this assumption is not applicable in VFL, DELPHI degenerates to GAZELLE. GALA (Zhang et al., 2021) outperforms GAZELLE by making the number of O3 (Rot) disproportional to N′superscript𝑁′N^{\prime} and eliminating all O4 (HstRot) on ⟦𝒚B⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝒚𝐵\llbracket\bm{y}_{B}\rrbracket. Therefore, we illustrate the SOTA diagonal method of GALA.

Fig. 2 shows the process of GALA’s diagonal method: 1) each diagonal of matrix 𝑿Asubscript𝑿𝐴\bm{X}_{A} is encoded into e~isubscript~𝑒𝑖\tilde{e}_{i}, following the diagonal order. e~0subscript~𝑒0\tilde{e}_{0} contains [A0,B1,C0,D1]subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵1subscript𝐶0subscript𝐷1[A_{0},B_{1},C_{0},D_{1}] and e~1subscript~𝑒1\tilde{e}_{1} contains [B0,C1,D0,A1]subscript𝐵0subscript𝐶1subscript𝐷0subscript𝐴1[B_{0},C_{1},D_{0},A_{1}]; 2) the vector 𝒚Bsubscript𝒚𝐵\bm{y}_{B} is encoded and encrypted, replicating the whole pattern, as ⟦[M0,M1,M0,M1]⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝑀0subscript𝑀1subscript𝑀0subscript𝑀1\llbracket[M_{0},M_{1},M_{0},M_{1}]\rrbracket. This RLWE-ct is sent from PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} to PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A}; 3) slot-wise multiplication is conducted by PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} for each e~isubscript~𝑒𝑖\tilde{e}_{i} and the received cipheretext; 4) PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} rotates ⟦[B0​M0,C​1​M1,D0​M0,A1​M1]⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝐵0subscript𝑀0𝐶1subscript𝑀1subscript𝐷0subscript𝑀0subscript𝐴1subscript𝑀1\llbracket[B_{0}M_{0},C1M_{1},D_{0}M_{0},A_{1}M_{1}]\rrbracket to ⟦[A1​M1,B0​M0,C1​M1,D0​M0]⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝐴1subscript𝑀1subscript𝐵0subscript𝑀0subscript𝐶1subscript𝑀1subscript𝐷0subscript𝑀0\llbracket[A_{1}M_{1},B_{0}M_{0},C_{1}M_{1},D_{0}M_{0}]\rrbracket; 5) PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} conducts slot-wise addition for the result of step (4) and ⟦[A0​M0,B1​M1,C0​M0,D1​M1]⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝐴0subscript𝑀0subscript𝐵1subscript𝑀1subscript𝐶0subscript𝑀0subscript𝐷1subscript𝑀1\llbracket[A_{0}M_{0},B_{1}M_{1},C_{0}M_{0},D_{1}M_{1}]\rrbracket. The obtained RLWE-ct is sent back to PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} for decryption. Shown in Tab. 2, GALA’s diagonal method maintains a small commnunication complexity same as the naive method as well as achieve a smaller computation complexity.

3.2. Coefficient Packing

Coefficient packing methods (Huang et al., 2022b; Hao et al., 2022) are recently proposed as SOTA methods, which do not follow previous standard encoding procedures, e.g., (Brakerski et al., 2014; Fan and Vercauteren, 2012; Cheon et al., 2017) and directly map cleartexts to coefficients of a plaintext polynomial. Cheetah (Huang et al., 2022b) is proposed as a MatMult method between matrix and vector. Iron (Hao et al., 2022) extends it to MatMult between matrices. Their computation is only one multiplication, with no other operation, e.g., O3 (Rot). However, they also suffer from high communication costs when applied in the VFL scenario, shown in Tab. 2. For illustration, we only introduce Cheetah (Huang et al., 2022b), which suits our task, i.e., Eq. 1. The process of Cheetah is: 1) X~Asubscript~𝑋𝐴\tilde{X}_{A} is constructed according to mapping X~A​[i⋅n+n−1−j]=𝑿A​[i,j]subscript~𝑋𝐴delimited-[]⋅𝑖𝑛𝑛1𝑗subscript𝑿𝐴𝑖𝑗\tilde{X}_{A}[i\cdot n+n-1-j]=\bm{X}_{A}[i,j]:

(2) X~A=subscript~𝑋𝐴absent\displaystyle\tilde{X}_{A}= A1​X0+A0​X1+B1​X2+B0​X3+subscript𝐴1superscript𝑋0subscript𝐴0superscript𝑋1subscript𝐵1superscript𝑋2limit-fromsubscript𝐵0superscript𝑋3\displaystyle A_{1}X^{0}+A_{0}X^{1}+B_{1}X^{2}+B_{0}X^{3}+

(4) X~A​y~B=subscript~𝑋𝐴subscript~𝑦𝐵absent\displaystyle\tilde{X}_{A}\tilde{y}_{B}= ⋯+(A0​M0+A1​M1)​X1+⋯+(B0​M0+B1​M1)​X3+⋯subscript𝐴0subscript𝑀0subscript𝐴1subscript𝑀1superscript𝑋1⋯limit-fromsubscript𝐵0subscript𝑀0subscript𝐵1subscript𝑀1superscript𝑋3\displaystyle\dots+(A_{0}M_{0}+A_{1}M_{1})X^{1}+\dots+(B_{0}M_{0}+B_{1}M_{1})X^{3}+

4) the MatMult results can be found with mapping (𝑿A​𝒚B)​[i]=(X~A​y~B)​[i⋅n+n−1]subscript𝑿𝐴subscript𝒚𝐵delimited-[]𝑖subscript~𝑋𝐴subscript~𝑦𝐵delimited-[]⋅𝑖𝑛𝑛1(\bm{X}_{A}\bm{y}_{B})[i]=(\tilde{X}_{A}\tilde{y}_{B})[i\cdot n+n-1]. Cheetah extracts specific RLWE coefficients to separate m𝑚m LWE-cts using (Chen et al., 2021a) to protect the privacy of the other unneeded coefficients. In our example, four LWE-cts are extracted from coefficients A0​M0+A1​M1,B0​M0+B1​M1,C0​M0+C1​M1,D0​M0+D1​M1subscript𝐴0subscript𝑀0subscript𝐴1subscript𝑀1subscript𝐵0subscript𝑀0subscript𝐵1subscript𝑀1subscript𝐶0subscript𝑀0subscript𝐶1subscript𝑀1subscript𝐷0subscript𝑀0subscript𝐷1subscript𝑀1A_{0}M_{0}+A_{1}M_{1},B_{0}M_{0}+B_{1}M_{1},C_{0}M_{0}+C_{1}M_{1},D_{0}M_{0}+D_{1}M_{1} and sent to PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} for decryption. As described in §2, we can calculate that these extracted LWE-cts are m(1+N)/2N×m(1+N)/2N\times larger than the original RLWE-ct, causing Large communication overheads.

4. MatMult Design for VFL Characteristics

With the guidance of comprehensive analysis in §3, we conclude characteristics of VFL’s MatMult operation and design a high-performant hybrid MatMult method accordingly, shown in Fig. 3. The characteristics of VFL’s MatMult are summarized below:

  • ∙∙\bullet

    C1 (Geo-Distributed Operand): the two operands are owned by geo-distributed parties of VFL. The encrypted operand is sent to the other party for MatMult, and the ciphertext result is transmitted back for decryption;

  • ∙∙\bullet

    C2 (Wide-Range Operand Size): as a machine learning technique, VFL often has varying batch sizes or feature dimensions, leading to varying operand sizes of MatMult, from large to small;

  • ∙∙\bullet

    C3 (Passive Decryption): the resulting ciphertexts of MatMult are transmitted to the party owning secret key for pure decryption without extra operations.

4.1. PackVFL’s Diagonal Method

The C1 (Geo-Distributed Operand) characteristic indicates a wide area network (WAN) situation with relatively small bandwidth. Large communication overheads of MatMult could severely slow down the training process. Besides, parties (companies) of VFL usually contain rich computing resources. Our design principle is: trying to reduce the computation complexity after guaranteeing that communication complexity is small enough.

4.1.1. Our Choice of Diagonal Method.

Considering the C1 (Geo-Distributed Operand) characteristic of VFL, we choose the diagonal method as our basic component. More specifically, comparing to the naive method, diagonal method can achieve less computation complexity while maintain the same communication complexity. For comparison with column-order and coefficient packing methods, we conduct an experiment where the bandwidth between PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} and PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} is 50MB/s (Jiang et al., 2021) and m=n=512,N=8192formulae-sequence𝑚𝑛512𝑁8192m=n=512,N=8192. The transmission time of the column-order method and Cheetah is beyond 10s, which is much larger than the computation overhead (under 1s) of diagonal method. Therefore, we choose the most suitable design path for the VFL MatMult.

However, through the systematical analysis in §3, we observe that the SOTA diagonal method of GALA is not optimal for computation efficiency. The reason is that GALA still contains unnecessary O3 (Rot) operations caused by its diagonal encoding way. Therefore, we propose PackVFL’s diagonal method, which adopts a different diagonal encoding to further replace the unnecessary O3 (Rot) with more efficient O4 (HstRot) operations.

PackVFL’s diagonal method encodes the matrix 𝑿Asubscript𝑿𝐴\bm{X}_{A} into:

(5) e~i​[j]=𝑿A​[jmodm,(i+j)modn],subscript~𝑒𝑖delimited-[]𝑗subscript𝑿𝐴modulo𝑗𝑚modulo𝑖𝑗𝑛\tilde{e}_{i}[j]=\bm{X}_{A}[j\mod m,\ (i+j)\mod n],

where i=0,1,…,min⁡(m,n)−1𝑖01…𝑚𝑛1i=0,1,...,\min(m,n)-1 and j=0,1,…,max⁡(m,n)−1𝑗01…𝑚𝑛1j=0,1,...,\max(m,n)-1. This equation is a general solution for both m≤n𝑚𝑛m\leq n (short-and-wide matrix) and m>n𝑚𝑛m>n (tall-and-skinny matrix) scenario. Fig. 4 illustrates the tall-and-skinny matrix case of m>n𝑚𝑛m>n. The process is described as: 1) each e~isubscript~𝑒𝑖\tilde{e}_{i} is generated along the diagonal, following Eq.. 5. For example, [A0,B1,C0,D1]subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵1subscript𝐶0subscript𝐷1[A_{0},B_{1},C_{0},D_{1}] are encoded into e~0subscript~𝑒0\tilde{e}_{0}; 2) the ciphertext ⟦𝒚B⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝒚𝐵\llbracket\bm{y}_{B}\rrbracket is constructed by replicating the whole yBsubscript𝑦𝐵y_{B} for mn𝑚𝑛\frac{m}{n} times; 3) n−1𝑛1n-1 O3 (Rot) need to be conducted on ⟦𝒚B⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝒚𝐵\llbracket\bm{y}_{B}\rrbracket to obtain n−1𝑛1n-1 new ciphertexts. We use O4 (HstRot) to replace them for better efficiency; 4) multiplication between e~isubscript~𝑒𝑖\tilde{e}_{i} and corresponding rotated ciphertext is performed; 5) we add the resulting ciphertexts to get ⟦𝑿A​𝒚B⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝑿𝐴subscript𝒚𝐵\llbracket\bm{X}_{A}\bm{y}_{B}\rrbracket. For the short-and-wide matrix case m≤n𝑚𝑛m\leq n, the construction of ⟦𝒚B⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝒚𝐵\llbracket\bm{y}_{B}\rrbracket needs no replication operation and additional RaS operations should be conducted. Readers could refer to Fig. 5(a) (m=n𝑚𝑛m=n) and Fig. 5(b) (m<n𝑚𝑛m<n) for more details.

Comparing to GALA in Tab. 2, PackVFL’s diagonal method substitutes min⁡(m,n)−1−log2⁡⌈nm⌉𝑚𝑛1subscript2𝑛𝑚\min(m,n)-1-\log_{2}\lceil\frac{n}{m}\rceil O3 (Rot) with the same number of O4 (HstRot) operations generally, achieving the optimal computation complexity. ⌈⋅⌉⋅\lceil\cdot\rceil stands for ceiling function. In the case of m≥n𝑚𝑛m\geq n, PackVFL’s diagonal method could substitute all O3 (Rot) with O4 (HstRot), while, in the case of m<n𝑚𝑛m<n, our diagonal method still needs log2⁡nmsubscript2𝑛𝑚\log_{2}\frac{n}{m} O3 (Rot) for the final RaS operations.

4.2. Input Packing and Partitioning

The characteristic C2 (Wide-Range Operand Size) indicates two scenarios: small size operands (m,n<N′𝑚𝑛superscript𝑁′m,n<N^{\prime}) and large size operand (m>N′𝑚superscript𝑁′m>N^{\prime} or n>N′𝑛superscript𝑁′n>N^{\prime}). The challenges of efficiently supporting small- and large-size operands are different. The former is to effectively leverage vacant slots for high-performant SIMD, while the latter one is to minimize redundant overheads across blocks as many as possible. We design input packing and partitioning, respectively.

4.2.1. Input Packing.

For scenario m,n<N′𝑚𝑛superscript𝑁′m,n<N^{\prime}, we pack multiple matrix diagonals into one plaintext polynomial to fully utilize the slots. In the beginning, we obtain the transformed matrix 𝑿′∈ℝm′×N′superscript𝑿′superscriptℝsuperscript𝑚′superscript𝑁′\bm{X}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{m^{\prime}\times N^{\prime}} with N′/nsuperscript𝑁′𝑛N^{\prime}/n sub-matrices vertically concatenated:

(6) 𝑿′​[imodm′,j+n​⌊im′⌋]=𝑿​[i,j],superscript𝑿′modulo𝑖superscript𝑚′𝑗𝑛𝑖superscript𝑚′𝑿𝑖𝑗\bm{X}^{\prime}[i\mod m^{\prime},\ j+n\lfloor\frac{i}{m^{\prime}}\rfloor]=\bm{X}[i,j],

where m′=⌈m​nN′⌉superscript𝑚′𝑚𝑛superscript𝑁′m^{\prime}=\lceil\frac{mn}{N^{\prime}}\rceil, ⌊⋅⌋⋅\lfloor\cdot\rfloor stands for floor function, i=0,1,…,m−1𝑖01…𝑚1i=0,1,...,m-1 and j=0,1,…,n−1𝑗01…𝑛1j=0,1,...,n-1. Then, we conduct diagonal encoding for 𝑿′superscript𝑿′\bm{X}^{\prime}, which is slightly different from Eq. 5. We illustrate it in Fig. 5(a) to compute 𝑿AT⟦𝒅⟧\bm{X}_{A}^{T}\llbracket\bm{d}\rrbracket. After we move the lower part of matrix 𝑿ATsuperscriptsubscript𝑿𝐴𝑇\bm{X}_{A}^{T} to the right and form a transformed matrix at step 2, the diagonal encoding is performed in parts. For example, at step 3, B0subscript𝐵0B_{0} is placed after A3subscript𝐴3A_{3}, not at the last slot of e~1subscript~𝑒1\tilde{e}_{1}, while D0subscript𝐷0D_{0} is set at the last slot. On the other side, the encrypted vector ⟦𝒅⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝒅\llbracket\bm{d}\rrbracket is expanded by replicating its pattern as ⟦[M0,M1,M2,M3,M0,M1,M2,M3]⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝑀0subscript𝑀1subscript𝑀2subscript𝑀3subscript𝑀0subscript𝑀1subscript𝑀2subscript𝑀3\llbracket[M_{0},M_{1},M_{2},M_{3},M_{0},M_{1},M_{2},M_{3}]\rrbracket, at step 1.

4.2.2. Input Partitioning.

For the scenarios m>N′𝑚superscript𝑁′m>N^{\prime} or n>N′𝑛superscript𝑁′n>N^{\prime}, we split the original matrix/vector into multiple blocks in slot size N′superscript𝑁′N^{\prime} and design tricks to further improve efficiency.

Large Operand Size is Common in VFL. VFL’s operand sizes are influenced by factors such as batch size, feature dimension, and the number of model parameters. These elements are increasingly scaling up in real-world applications. For instance, within the realm of machine learning, VFL is progressively adopting larger batch sizes — such as 15,000 (Keskar et al., 2016), 4,096 (Hoffer et al., 2017), and 8,192 (Lin et al., 2020) — to enhance parallelism. Besides, the era of big data sees a surge in datasets with high feature dimensions, such as 22,283, 19,993 (Liu et al., 2017), reflecting a growing trend (Zhai et al., 2014). In addition, as GPT (Brown et al., 2020) gains widespread attention, large models, such as those with 65 billion (Touvron et al., 2023) and 130 billion parameters (Zeng et al., 2022), are becoming a focal point of research.

In the case m>N′≥n𝑚superscript𝑁′𝑛m>N^{\prime}\geq n, we horizontally split the original matrix 𝑿𝑿\bm{X} into mN′𝑚superscript𝑁′\frac{m}{N^{\prime}} sub-matrices, then conduct the diagonal method between each sub-matrix and ⟦𝒚B⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝒚𝐵\llbracket\bm{y}_{B}\rrbracket separately. Besides, we only need to complete one group of O4 (HstRot) on ⟦𝒚B⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝒚𝐵\llbracket\bm{y}_{B}\rrbracket for all sub-matrices. For the case m≤N′<n𝑚superscript𝑁′𝑛m\leq N^{\prime}<n, we provide an example in Fig. 5(b) to compute 𝑿A⟦⟨𝒘A⟩2⟧\bm{X}_{A}\llbracket\langle\bm{w}_{A}\rangle_{2}\rrbracket. <⁣⋅⁣>⋅<\cdot> stands for the secret share. At step 1&2, we vertically divide both the original matrix 𝑿Asubscript𝑿𝐴\bm{X}_{A} and vector ⟨𝒘A⟩2subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝒘𝐴2\langle\bm{w}_{A}\rangle_{2} into nN′𝑛superscript𝑁′\frac{n}{N^{\prime}} blocks. At step 3, we conduct diagonal method for each block. Originally, we will obtain nN′𝑛superscript𝑁′\frac{n}{N^{\prime}} ciphertext results and send them to PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} for decryption, which vastly increases communication complexity. However, we bring forward the addition operation of results in different blocks at step 4. Hence, we need only one transmission of the aggregated ciphertext.

4.3. Lazy Rotate-and-Sum.

Considering the C3 (Passive Decryption) characteristic, we design the Lazy Rotate-and-Sum (RaS) technique. The main idea is to eliminate the remaining ciphertext RaS operations, which contains O3 (Rot), and replace them with cleartext sum-up computation. We provide illustrations in both Fig. 5(a) and Fig. 5(b). Taking Fig. 5(a) as an example, after step 4, PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} obtains ⟦[A0​M0+A1​M1,B1​M1+B2​M2,A2​M2+A3​M3,B3​M3+B0​M0,⋯]⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝐴0subscript𝑀0subscript𝐴1subscript𝑀1subscript𝐵1subscript𝑀1subscript𝐵2subscript𝑀2subscript𝐴2subscript𝑀2subscript𝐴3subscript𝑀3subscript𝐵3subscript𝑀3subscript𝐵0subscript𝑀0⋯\llbracket[A_{0}M_{0}+A_{1}M_{1},B_{1}M_{1}+B_{2}M_{2},A_{2}M_{2}+A_{3}M_{3},B_{3}M_{3}+B_{0}M_{0},\cdots]\rrbracket. Naively, a set of time-consuming RaS operations was necessary to aggregate intermediate elements within the ciphertext before sending it to PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} for decryption. However, since PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} performs no additional operations on the ciphertext beyond decryption and directly returns the results, the slots of the ciphertext that need decryption still align correctly with the indices of the resulting cleartext vectors. Consequently, we can defer the RaS operations after the decryption process. Ignoring the masking precedures at step 5&6, we will explain them in §5.1. PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} directly sends ⟦[A0​M0+A1​M1,B1​M1+B2​M2,A2​M2+A3​M3,B3​M3+B0​M0,⋯]⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝐴0subscript𝑀0subscript𝐴1subscript𝑀1subscript𝐵1subscript𝑀1subscript𝐵2subscript𝑀2subscript𝐴2subscript𝑀2subscript𝐴3subscript𝑀3subscript𝐵3subscript𝑀3subscript𝐵0subscript𝑀0⋯\llbracket[A_{0}M_{0}+A_{1}M_{1},B_{1}M_{1}+B_{2}M_{2},A_{2}M_{2}+A_{3}M_{3},B_{3}M_{3}+B_{0}M_{0},\cdots]\rrbracket to PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} and obtains [A0​M0+A1​M1,B1​M1+B2​M2,A2​M2+A3​M3,B3​M3+B0​M0,⋯]subscript𝐴0subscript𝑀0subscript𝐴1subscript𝑀1subscript𝐵1subscript𝑀1subscript𝐵2subscript𝑀2subscript𝐴2subscript𝑀2subscript𝐴3subscript𝑀3subscript𝐵3subscript𝑀3subscript𝐵0subscript𝑀0⋯[A_{0}M_{0}+A_{1}M_{1},B_{1}M_{1}+B_{2}M_{2},A_{2}M_{2}+A_{3}M_{3},B_{3}M_{3}+B_{0}M_{0},\cdots] after decryption. Finally, we could substitute the RaS operations with cleartext A0​M0+A1​M1+A2​M2+A3​M3,B0​M0+B1​M1+B2​M2+B3​M3,C0​M0+C1​M1+C2​M2+C3​M3,D0​M0+D1​M1+D2​M2+D3​M3subscript𝐴0subscript𝑀0subscript𝐴1subscript𝑀1subscript𝐴2subscript𝑀2subscript𝐴3subscript𝑀3subscript𝐵0subscript𝑀0subscript𝐵1subscript𝑀1subscript𝐵2subscript𝑀2subscript𝐵3subscript𝑀3subscript𝐶0subscript𝑀0subscript𝐶1subscript𝑀1subscript𝐶2subscript𝑀2subscript𝐶3subscript𝑀3subscript𝐷0subscript𝑀0subscript𝐷1subscript𝑀1subscript𝐷2subscript𝑀2subscript𝐷3subscript𝑀3A_{0}M_{0}+A_{1}M_{1}+A_{2}M_{2}+A_{3}M_{3},B_{0}M_{0}+B_{1}M_{1}+B_{2}M_{2}+B_{3}M_{3},C_{0}M_{0}+C_{1}M_{1}+C_{2}M_{2}+C_{3}M_{3},D_{0}M_{0}+D_{1}M_{1}+D_{2}M_{2}+D_{3}M_{3}.

Combining the above three components of our hybrid MatMult method, we can also compute the complexity of PackVFL for the cases of m>N′𝑚superscript𝑁′m>N^{\prime} or n>N′𝑛superscript𝑁′n>N^{\prime}, shown in Tab. 3.

PackVFL v.s. GALA. Besides the improvement of diagonal method explained in 4.1, PackVFL also has the following advantages over GALA: 1) PackVFL’s diagonal and input packing method are formally defined with equations. In contrast, GALA introduces its method only using legends and textual descriptions, which could lead to misinterpretation and poor generalizability; 2) GALA lacks mechanisms for input partitioning, whereas PackVFL incorporates sophisticated mechanisms that eliminate redundant operations when processing segmented blocks. Our experiments demonstrate a significant improvement in PackVFL when the operand size, e.g., feature dimension or batch size, is large in §7; 3) PackVFL extends the concept of lazy RaS in GALA beyond its original application from SS ciphertext to cleartext, thereby increasing its practical utility and relevance across diverse contexts. Additionally, in the VFL scenario, PackVFL introduces the innovative mechanism, i.e., cleartext inverse RaS, to facilitate the implementation of lazy RaS in §5.2.

5. Adaption Design to SOTA VFL Algorithms

In this section, we provide a comprehensive guidance on integrating the proposed PackedHE MatMult method by explaining how to apply it to representative VFL algorithms, e.g., VFL-LinR (Yang et al., 2019b), CAESAR (Chen et al., 2021b), and VFL-NN (Zhang and Zhu, 2020). These three algorithms are fundamental and well-recognized by the VFL community (Yang et al., 2023). Other algorithms, e.g., (Huang et al., 2022a; Cai et al., 2022b; Yang et al., 2019c, a; Liu et al., 2019; Li et al., 2020; Fu et al., 2022), which also contain MatMult operations, can similarly apply PackVFL. Accelerating HE-based VFL algorithms, e.g., (Cheng et al., 2021), whose core computation is not MatMult, will be our future work. For CAESAR and VFL-NN, we analyzes their unique algorithmic properties and made three adaption designs to improve efficiency further, as shown in Fig. 3:

  • ∙∙\bullet

    Multiplication Level Reduction, which optimizes CAESAR’s calculation process to reduce the number of accumulated multiplication over a single ciphertext for more efficient PackedHE parameters;

  • ∙∙\bullet

    Cleartext Inverse Rotate-and-Sum (RaS), which is designed to make our MatMult method feasible for CAESAR after multiplication level reduction;

  • ∙∙\bullet

    Transposed Matrices’ Diagonal Conversion, which is a conversion mechanism between diagonal encodings of matrix and its transpose to reduce half of the communication cost in VFL-NN.

5.1. Adaption to VFL-LinR

VFL-LinR (Yang et al., 2019b) securely trains a linear regression model, involving three parties. PA,PBsubscript𝑃𝐴subscript𝑃𝐵P_{A},P_{B} hold 𝑿A,𝑿B,𝒚Bsubscript𝑿𝐴subscript𝑿𝐵subscript𝒚𝐵\bm{X}_{A},\bm{X}_{B},\bm{y}_{B} and train weights 𝜽A,𝜽Bsubscript𝜽𝐴subscript𝜽𝐵\bm{\theta}_{A},\bm{\theta}_{B} with the help of a third-party arbiter PCsubscript𝑃𝐶P_{C}. PA,PBsubscript𝑃𝐴subscript𝑃𝐵P_{A},P_{B} exchange encrypted intermediate results ⟦𝒖A⟧,⟦𝒅⟧\llbracket\bm{u}_{A}\rrbracket,\llbracket\bm{d}\rrbracket and calculate over them to obtain the encrypted model updates ⟦δ​Lδ​𝜽A⟧,⟦δ​Lδ​𝜽B⟧\llbracket\frac{\delta L}{\delta\bm{\theta}_{A}}\rrbracket,\llbracket\frac{\delta L}{\delta\bm{\theta}_{B}}\rrbracket. Then, PA,PBsubscript𝑃𝐴subscript𝑃𝐵P_{A},P_{B} add random masks on the updates and send them to PCsubscript𝑃𝐶P_{C} for decryption. Fig. 5(a) illustrates the computation process of PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A}, and the operations of PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} could refer to Alg. 1.

Starting from step 2 in Tab. 1 of VFL-LinR (Yang et al., 2019b), PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} receives the ⟦𝒖A⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝒖𝐴\llbracket\bm{u}_{A}\rrbracket from PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A}, computes the ⟦𝒅⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝒅\llbracket\bm{d}\rrbracket with the replicated encoding, and sends it to PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A}. Then, PA,PBsubscript𝑃𝐴subscript𝑃𝐵P_{A},P_{B} conduct vertical input packing over plaintext matrix 𝑿AT,𝑿BTsuperscriptsubscript𝑿𝐴𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑿𝐵𝑇\bm{X}_{A}^{T},\bm{X}_{B}^{T}, and generate m​nN′𝑚𝑛superscript𝑁′\frac{mn}{N^{\prime}} plaintext 𝒆A,i,𝒆B,isubscript𝒆𝐴𝑖subscript𝒆𝐵𝑖\bm{e}_{A,i},\bm{e}_{B,i}. For each plaintext, PA,PBsubscript𝑃𝐴subscript𝑃𝐵P_{A},P_{B} conduct multiplication with corresponding the rotated ciphertext HstRotL(⟦𝒅⟧,i)\mbox{HstRotL}(\llbracket\bm{d}\rrbracket,i). Next, PA,PBsubscript𝑃𝐴subscript𝑃𝐵P_{A},P_{B} separately sum up the results. After that, PA,PBsubscript𝑃𝐴subscript𝑃𝐵P_{A},P_{B} send the masked ciphertexts to PCsubscript𝑃𝐶P_{C}. PCsubscript𝑃𝐶P_{C} decrypts them and sends the results back. PA,PBsubscript𝑃𝐴subscript𝑃𝐵P_{A},P_{B} remove the masks and apply the lazy RaS to obtain gradients for model update. The process ends at step 4 in Tab. 1 of VFL-LinR.

5.2. Adaption to CAESAR

CAESAR (Chen et al., 2021b) is a vertical federated logistic regression algorithm combining HE and SS to enhance the security, containing two parties. PA,PBsubscript𝑃𝐴subscript𝑃𝐵P_{A},P_{B} distributely train on 𝑿A,𝑿B,𝒚Bsubscript𝑿𝐴subscript𝑿𝐵subscript𝒚𝐵\bm{X}_{A},\bm{X}_{B},\bm{y}_{B} to obtain weights 𝒘A,𝒘Bsubscript𝒘𝐴subscript𝒘𝐵\bm{w}_{A},\bm{w}_{B}. CAESAR is a SOTA end-to-end training algorithm. Our modifications are mainly located in Protocol 1 of CAESAR. Besides, we also make extra designs, i.e., multiplication level reduction and plaintext inverse RaS, to further improve efficiency.

Taking the prediction calculation process as an example, we show the modification to Protocol 1 of CAESAR. PA,PBsubscript𝑃𝐴subscript𝑃𝐵P_{A},P_{B} initialize 𝒘A,𝒘Bsubscript𝒘𝐴subscript𝒘𝐵\bm{w}_{A},\bm{w}_{B}, generate and exchange shares of model weights. More specifically, PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} generates shares ⟨𝒘A⟩1,⟨𝒘A⟩2subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝒘𝐴1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝒘𝐴2\langle\bm{w}_{A}\rangle_{1},\langle\bm{w}_{A}\rangle_{2} (⟨𝒘A⟩1+⟨𝒘A⟩2=𝒘Asubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝒘𝐴1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝒘𝐴2subscript𝒘𝐴\langle\bm{w}_{A}\rangle_{1}+\langle\bm{w}_{A}\rangle_{2}=\bm{w}_{A}), holds ⟨𝒘A⟩1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝒘𝐴1\langle\bm{w}_{A}\rangle_{1}, and sends ⟨𝒘A⟩2subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝒘𝐴2\langle\bm{w}_{A}\rangle_{2} to PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B}, where ⟨⋅⟩delimited-⟨⟩⋅\langle\cdot\rangle stands for a secret share. Next, PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} conducts 𝑿A⟦⟨𝒘A⟩2⟧\bm{X}_{A}\llbracket\langle\bm{w}_{A}\rangle_{2}\rrbracket at line 11 in Algorithm 1 of CAESAR (Chen et al., 2021b).

As shown in Fig. 5(b) and Alg. 2, at first, PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} divides ⟨𝒘A⟩2subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝒘𝐴2\langle\bm{w}_{A}\rangle_{2} into mN′𝑚superscript𝑁′\frac{m}{N^{\prime}} blocks, encrypts, and sends them to PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A}. PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} conducts input partitioning on matrix 𝑿Asubscript𝑿𝐴\bm{X}_{A} and obtains blocks. For each vector and matrix block, PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} performs the MatMult method without the final RaS operations. Next, PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} conducts addition over the results of all blocks, randomly generates vector 𝒓Asubscript𝒓𝐴\bm{r}_{A} and substracts it from the resulting ciphertext. Finally, PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} sends the outcome to PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B}. PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} decrypts it and applies lazy RaS. PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} conducts cleartext RaS over 𝒓Asubscript𝒓𝐴\bm{r}_{A}.

5.2.1. Multiplication Level Reduction.

The efficiency of PackedHE is highly related to its parameters. Parameters allowing less multiplication refer to more efficient PackedHE operations. Therefore, we modify the computation process of CAESAR to reduce the multiplication level. More detailedly, in line 21 of the Algorithm 1 in CAESAR, ⟦𝒆⟧T=⟦𝒚^⟧−𝒚=q0+q1⟦𝒛⟧+q2⟦𝒛3⟧−𝒚\llbracket\bm{e}\rrbracket^{T}=\llbracket\hat{\bm{y}}\rrbracket-\bm{y}=q_{0}+q_{1}\llbracket\bm{z}\rrbracket+q_{2}\llbracket\bm{z}^{3}\rrbracket-\bm{y} is computed, which consumes one multiplication level, i.e., q1⟦𝒛⟧q_{1}\llbracket\bm{z}\rrbracket and q2⟦𝒛3⟧q_{2}\llbracket\bm{z}^{3}\rrbracket. Then, ⟦𝒈B⟧=⟦𝒆⟧T𝑿B\llbracket\bm{g}_{B}\rrbracket=\llbracket\bm{e}\rrbracket^{T}\bm{X}_{B} is computed based on the resulted ⟦𝒆⟧T\llbracket\bm{e}\rrbracket^{T}, which needs one more multiplication level. We integrate them to:

(7) ⟦𝒈B⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝒈𝐵\displaystyle\llbracket\bm{g}_{B}\rrbracket =⟦e⟧T𝑿B=(⟦𝒚^⟧−𝒚)T𝑿B=(q0+q1⟦𝒛⟧+q2⟦𝒛3⟧−𝒚)𝑿B\displaystyle=\llbracket e\rrbracket^{T}\bm{X}_{B}=(\llbracket\hat{\bm{y}}\rrbracket-\bm{y})^{T}\bm{X}_{B}=(q_{0}+q_{1}\llbracket\bm{z}\rrbracket+q_{2}\llbracket\bm{z}^{3}\rrbracket-\bm{y})\bm{X}_{B}
=(q0𝟏→−𝒚)𝑿B+(q1𝑿B)⟦𝒛⟧+(q2𝑿B)⟦𝒛3⟧,\displaystyle=(q_{0}\overrightarrow{\bm{1}}-\bm{y})\bm{X}_{B}+(q_{1}\bm{X}_{B})\llbracket\bm{z}\rrbracket+(q_{2}\bm{X}_{B})\llbracket\bm{z}^{3}\rrbracket,

which decreases the multiplication level by one since the computation of (q1𝑿B)⟦𝒛⟧(q_{1}\bm{X}_{B})\llbracket\bm{z}\rrbracket and (q2𝑿B)⟦𝒛3⟧(q_{2}\bm{X}_{B})\llbracket\bm{z}^{3}\rrbracket only need one multiplication level.

5.2.2. Cleartext Inverse RaS.

However, Eq. 7 introduces extra cleartext addition term (q0​𝟏→−𝒚)⋅XB⋅subscript𝑞0→1𝒚subscript𝑋𝐵(q_{0}\overrightarrow{\bm{1}}-\bm{y})\cdot{X}_{B} before secretly sharing ⟦𝒈B⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝒈𝐵\llbracket\bm{g}_{B}\rrbracket. We cannot directly perform lazy RaS over the shares because the addition term needs no inner sum operation. One option is to separately share the above cleartext addition term and the remaining ciphertext term, only conducting lazy RaS over the share of the ciphertext term. But this approach increases communication cost. Therefore, we design the cleartext inverse RaS method, which iteratively conducts split and concatenation over the cleartext plaintext term before addition, which properly aligns the number of required RaS between cleartext and ciphertext addition terms. For example, after one inverse RaS, cleartext vector [M0,M1]subscript𝑀0subscript𝑀1[M_{0},M_{1}] turns to [M0,0,M1,0,M0,1,M1,1]subscript𝑀00subscript𝑀10subscript𝑀01subscript𝑀11[M_{0,0},M_{1,0},M_{0,1},M_{1,1}], where M0=M0,0+M0,1,M1=M1,0+M1,1formulae-sequencesubscript𝑀0subscript𝑀00subscript𝑀01subscript𝑀1subscript𝑀10subscript𝑀11M_{0}=M_{0,0}+M_{0,1},M_{1}=M_{1,0}+M_{1,1}.

5.3. Adaption to VFL-NN

VFL-NN (Zhang and Zhu, 2020) implements a distributed neural network (Abiodun et al., 2018) via the SplitNN (Vepakomma et al., 2018) architecture. It divides NN layers into PA,PBsubscript𝑃𝐴subscript𝑃𝐵P_{A},P_{B}, separately owning 𝑿A,𝑿B,𝒚Bsubscript𝑿𝐴subscript𝑿𝐵subscript𝒚𝐵\bm{X}_{A},\bm{X}_{B},\bm{y}_{B}. VFL-NN, capable of handling more complex networks, addresses ”harder” tasks. We also refer to the VFL-NN implementation in FATE (Liu et al., 2021). In VFL-NN, PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} feeds data into the bottom layer and obtains embedding 𝜶A∈ℝm×nsubscript𝜶𝐴superscriptℝ𝑚𝑛\bm{\alpha}_{A}\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times n}, where m𝑚m is the batch size, and n𝑛n is the number of neurons in the bottom layer. Then, PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} encrypts 𝜶Asubscript𝜶𝐴\bm{\alpha}_{A} into ⟦𝜶A⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝜶𝐴\llbracket\bm{\alpha}_{A}\rrbracket and sends them to PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} who contains the interactive and top layers. Next, PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} conducts two separate MatMult ⟦𝜶A⟧⋅𝑾A\llbracket\bm{\alpha}_{A}\rrbracket\cdot\bm{W}_{A} and 𝜹act⋅⟦𝜶A⟧=(⟦𝜶AT⟧⋅𝜹actT)T\bm{\delta}_{\mbox{act}}\cdot\llbracket\bm{\alpha}_{A}\rrbracket=(\llbracket\bm{\alpha}_{A}^{T}\rrbracket\cdot\bm{\delta}_{\mbox{act}}^{T})^{T} in the forward and backward propagation calculation. We have two observations: 1) the MatMult is between matrices; 2) ⟦𝜶A⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝜶𝐴\llbracket\bm{\alpha}_{A}\rrbracket locates at opposite positions in two MatMult. For the first observation, we choose to apply diagonal encoding on the ciphertext matrix instead of the cleartext matrix to eliminate all the existing O4 (HstRot), which is unprecedented in earlier works.

5.3.1. Transposed Matrices’ Diagonal Conversion.

For the second observation, we designed the transposed matrices’ diagonal conversion mechanism, which further reduces half of the communication cost. Therefore, instead of transmitting both ⟦𝜶A⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝜶𝐴\llbracket\bm{\alpha}_{A}\rrbracket and ⟦𝜶AT⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscriptsubscript𝜶𝐴𝑇\llbracket\bm{\alpha}_{A}^{T}\rrbracket from PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} to PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B}, we could only transmit ⟦𝜶A⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝜶𝐴\llbracket\bm{\alpha}_{A}\rrbracket. The mechanism allows conversion between diagonal encodings e~~𝑒\tilde{e} and e~′superscript~𝑒′\tilde{e}^{\prime} of transposed matrices:

(8) e~i′=RotR(\displaystyle\tilde{e}_{i}^{\prime}=\mbox{RotR}( e~​[(min⁡(m,n)−i)modmin⁡(m,n)],~𝑒delimited-[]modulo𝑚𝑛𝑖𝑚𝑛\displaystyle\tilde{e}[(\min(m,n)-i)\mod\min(m,n)],
max(m,n)−min(m,n)+i).\displaystyle\max(m,n)-\min(m,n)+i).

Shown in Alg. 3 and Fig. 5(c), our modification to forward propagation process starts from line 5 in Alg. 1 of VFL-NN (Zhang and Zhu, 2020). First, PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} diagonally encodes, encrypts ⟦𝜶A⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝜶𝐴\llbracket\bm{\alpha}_{A}\rrbracket, and sends it to PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B}. PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} generates random mask ϵB∈ℝm×n′subscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝐵superscriptℝ𝑚superscript𝑛′\bm{\epsilon}_{B}\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times n^{\prime}}, where n′superscript𝑛′n^{\prime} is the number of neurons in the interactive layer 𝑾A∈ℝn×n′subscript𝑾𝐴superscriptℝ𝑛superscript𝑛′\bm{W}_{A}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n^{\prime}}. For each column k𝑘k of 𝑾Asubscript𝑾𝐴\bm{W}_{A} in parallel, PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} conducts MatMult between ⟦𝜶A⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝜶𝐴\llbracket\bm{\alpha}_{A}\rrbracket and 𝑾Asubscript𝑾𝐴\bm{W}_{A} to obtain ⟦𝒛A[:k]⟧\llbracket\bm{z}_{A}[:k]\rrbracket, where [:,k]:𝑘[:,k] represents the k𝑘k column of matrix. The MatMult is efficient since we eliminate all O4 (HstRot). Besides, PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} masks each resulted ciphertext. Next, PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} sends them to PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} for decryption and lazy RaS. In the idle period of waiting for PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A}’s response, PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} conducts transposed matrices’ diagonal conversion according to Eq. 8 and obtains ⟦𝜶AT⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscriptsubscript𝜶𝐴𝑇\llbracket\bm{\alpha}_{A}^{T}\rrbracket.

Shown in Alg. 4 and Fig. 5(c), our modification to the backward propagation process starts from line 3 in Alg. 2 of VFL-NN (Zhang and Zhu, 2020). First, PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} randomly generates mask ϵB′∈ℤn′×nsubscriptsuperscriptbold-italic-ϵ′𝐵superscriptℤsuperscript𝑛′𝑛\bm{\epsilon}^{\prime}_{B}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n^{\prime}\times n}. Then, for each column k𝑘k of 𝜹actTsuperscriptsubscript𝜹act𝑇\bm{\delta}_{\mbox{act}}^{T}, PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} conducts MatMult between ⟦𝜶AT⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscriptsubscript𝜶𝐴𝑇\llbracket\bm{\alpha}_{A}^{T}\rrbracket and 𝜹actT​[:,k]superscriptsubscript𝜹act𝑇:𝑘\bm{\delta}_{\mbox{act}}^{T}[:,k], where 𝜹act∈ℝn′×msubscript𝜹actsuperscriptℝsuperscript𝑛′𝑚\bm{\delta}_{\mbox{act}}\in\mathbb{R}^{n^{\prime}\times m} is the error back-propagated from the top layer. Besides, PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} conducts addition between ⟦𝜶AT⟧+𝜹actT[:,k]\llbracket\bm{\alpha}_{A}^{T}\rrbracket+\bm{\delta}_{\mbox{act}}^{T}[:,k] and ϵBT′​[:,k]superscriptsubscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝐵superscript𝑇′:𝑘\bm{\epsilon}_{B}^{{}^{\prime}T}[:,k]. Finally, PBsubscript𝑃𝐵P_{B} collects ⟦𝜶AT​𝜹actT+ϵBT′⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscriptsubscript𝜶𝐴𝑇superscriptsubscript𝜹act𝑇superscriptsubscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝐵superscript𝑇′\llbracket\bm{\alpha}_{A}^{T}\bm{\delta}_{\mbox{act}}^{T}+\bm{\epsilon}_{B}^{{}^{\prime}T}\rrbracket and sends it to PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A}. PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} decrypts them, conducts lazy RaS and transpose to obtain 𝜹act​𝜶A+ϵB′subscript𝜹actsubscript𝜶𝐴subscriptsuperscriptbold-italic-ϵ′𝐵\bm{\delta}_{\mbox{act}}\bm{\alpha}_{A}+\bm{\epsilon}^{\prime}_{B}.

6. Correctness and Security Analysis

PackVFL innovates on the top of but didn’t change basic PackedHE operations. Therefore, ciphertext correctness/security is fully protected by PackedHE, which is well recognized (Juvekar et al., 2018; Zhang et al., 2021). Besides, PackVFL substitutes Paillier with PackedHE in HE-based VFL for cryptographic computation, which enhances the ciphertext security since PackedHE is quantum-resilient (Nejatollahi et al., 2019) and Paillier is vulnerable to post-quantum attacks (Shor, 1999).

We empirically show that our end-to-end training accuracy loss is small enough in §7.1. In addition, security of VFL protocols varies based on their origionally designed exposure of cleartexts during training. For instance, VFL-LinR and VFL-NN are more susceptible to attacks than CAESAR due to greater information exposure. CAESAR exposes no intermediate cleartext results during training. As a plug-in method, PackVFL also didn’t modify the original federated protocols (Yang et al., 2019b; Chen et al., 2021b; Zhang and Zhu, 2020). Thus, their security analysis of VFL protocols, under various threat models, e.g., semi-honest/malicious, remains valid and can be our reference.

7. Experiment

Setup and Implementation. The experiments are conducted on three x86 servers, each with 128GB memory and 40-core Intel Xeon Glod 5115 CPU. The bandwidth and latency among servers are 50MB/s and 20ms, respectively. We build our framework based on FATE (Liu et al., 2021) and Lattigo (lat, 2022). We compile the CKKS (Cheon et al., 2017) interfaces of Lattigo with CGO 555https://golang.org/cmd/cgo/, implement our MatMult method over the compiled interfaces, and integrate it into VFL-LinR, CAESAR, and VFL-NN of FATE. The implementation of GALA refers to the open-source codes 666https://github.com/mc2-project/delphi.

Dataset. We utilize the SUSY dataset (Baldi et al., 2014) to conduct the efficiency experiments, focusing on both computation and communication aspects. To meet different requirements of data size, we adjust the sample count and feature dimensions through sampling. Additionally, we use the NUS-WIDE dataset (Chua et al., 2009) for the accuracy experiments, since the NUS-WIDE dataset contains heterogeneous features, i.e., text and image features, and is naturally apt for the VFL scenario 777We didn’t use other datasets with homogeneous features, such as MNIST (LeCun et al., 1998), CIFAR (Krizhevsky et al., 2009), and LEAF (Caldas et al., 2018).. We separate its text and image features into two parties and create the vertically partitioned data situation. From the 81 groundtruth concepts, we select the most balanced one to serve as the label for our binary classification task.

Baseline. The baselines of the end-to-end experiment are utilizing Paillier and GALA (Zhang et al., 2021) for MatMult computation in VFL-LinR, CAESAR, and VFL-NN, respectively. When batch size and feature dimension exceed N′=N/2=4096superscript𝑁′𝑁24096N^{\prime}=N/2=4096, we do not show the results of GALA because GALA have no specific design of input partitioning.

Selection of PackedHE Parameters. The parameters of PackedHE, i.e., N,q𝑁𝑞N,q, are pretty relative to the efficiency and security. q𝑞q also decides the multiplication level. We set N=8192𝑁8192N=8192 for all the experiments. We set log⁡q=156𝑞156\log q=156 for the naive method and GALA in CAESAR, which allows two multiplication operations, and sets log⁡q=122𝑞122\log q=122 for the other methods, which allows one multiplication operation. According to (Albrecht et al., 2021), the involved PackedHE MatMult methods offer a 192-bit security level. Therefore, we set the security level of the adopted Paillier as 128-bit (Catalano et al., 2001) for a fair comparison.

7.1. End-to-End VFL

We show the end-to-end acceleration of GALA and PackVFL over Paillier for the VFL training process in Fig. 6. We could conclude that PackVFL always has the most significant acceleration ratio, which reflects speed gains over Paillier-based VFL algorithms, in different situations. Additionally, we demonstrate that PackVFL does not compromise the accuracy of the VFL training process in Tab. 4.

7.1.1. Accelerating VFL-LinR.

In Fig. 6(a) and Fig. 6(b), we vary the batch size and feature dimension, fixing the feature dimension and batch size as 50 and 512, respectively. As batch size and feature dimension increase, the speedups of GALA and PackVFL over Paillier also increase. PackVFL is more efficient than GALA from the beginning, with fewer rotation operations O3 (Rot) and O4 (HstRot). PackVFL achieves the largest acceleration ratio up to 33.30×33.30\times over Paillier-based VFL-LinR when feature dimension extends to 12800 in Fig. 6(b). As explained in §4.2, scenarios involving large feature dimensions are quite typical in VFL.

7.1.2. Accelerating CAESAR.

In Fig. 6(c) and Fig. 6(d), we also fix feature dimension and batch size as 50 and 512, separately. The speedups of GALA and PackVFL over Paillier in CAESAR are all smaller than those in VFL-LinR because CAESAR also contains many SS operations, which PackVFL cannot accelerate. Besides, the performance of GALA degrades more than PackVFL because they have no design for reducing multiplication level, thus leading to a less efficient PackedHE parameter log⁡q=156𝑞156\log q=156. PackVFL still has the best performance from the beginning, with the largest speedup over Paillier up to 3.22×3.22\times.

7.1.3. Accelerating VFL-NN.

In Fig. 6(e) and Fig. 6(f), we vary the batch size and number of hidden units in the bottom model, fixing the number of hidden units in the bottom model and batch size as 32 and 32, respectively. Besides, the feature dimension is 50, the number of hidden units in the interactive layer is 32, and the top model is linear. We show that PackVFL’s acceleration for VFL-NN is much more significant than acceleration for both VFL-LinR and CAESAR. The reason is that PackVFL chooses to diagonally encode the ciphertext matrix. which eliminate all O3 (Rot) and O4 (HstRot). Therefore, PackVFL has the most considerable speedup over Paillier up to 51.52×51.52\times for VFL-NN. Besides, GALA is not explicitly designed for this scenario containing MatMult between matrices. They are much slower than PackVFL.

7.1.4. Communication Analysis.

We also show the communication costs of different methods in Fig. 7, where the batch size is set to 512 for CAESAR and 32 for VFL-NN. The feature dimension is set to 800 for VFL-LinR and 50 for VFL-NN. The number of hidden units in the interactive layer is 32 for VFL-NN 888A smaller batch size of 32 was selected to avoid exceeding server memory limits.. The communication cost is computed as the sum of ciphertexts that a single party receives and sends in one training iteration.

PackVFL generally has less communication cost than Paillier and GALA. More concretely, in Fig. 7(a) and Fig. 7(b), with small batch sizes, the Paillier has less communication cost than PackVFL since Paillier implementation in FATE (Liu et al., 2021) has extra engineering optimizations. As batch size increases, PackVFL outperforms Paillier, with the largest improvement of 3.94×3.94\times and 2.83×2.83\times over VFL-LinR and CAESAR, respectively. In Fig. 7(c), PackVFL has less communication cost than Paillier for VFL-NN, even when batch size is small. It has the largest improvement of 7.14×7.14\times. The reason is the adoption of vertical input packing and transposed matrices’ diagonal conversion.

Besides, for VFL-LinR, PackVFL has the same communication cost as GALA for VFL-LinR, as shown in Fig. 7(a), because their transmitted ciphertext amount and PackedHE parameters are both equal. For CAESAR, shown in Fig 7(b), the communication costs of GALA are larger than PackVFL since their parameter q=156𝑞156q=156 is larger, resulting in a larger ciphertext size. In VFL-NN, PackVFL has a larger advantage over GALA, shown in Fig. 7(c). They suffer from extensive communication overhead since they still diagonally encode the cleartext matrix. The matrix to be encrypted can only be encrypted by each row/column with no input packing.

7.1.5. Model Accuracy Discussion.

We demonstrate that PackVFL maintains consistent accuracy in Tab. 4. Our comparison of loss and AUC between Paillier-based VFL algorithms and PackVFL reveals minimal discrepancies, with differences not surpassing the third decimal place. This remarkable precision is attributable to the negligible noise inherent in the CKKS scheme, which could be effectively managed through rescaling operations (Dathathri et al., 2020) and aligns well with the generalization capabilities of machine learning models (Neelakantan et al., 2015).

7.2. Computaion Analysis for MatMult

In this part, we compare the computation efficiency of PackVFL, naive and GALA on the MatMult task between ciphertext vector and cleartext matrix. As shown in Tab. 5, we conduct experiments over different matrix sizes and provide the consuming time and speedup of PackVFL compared to the baselines. We obtain the following conclusions: 1) PackVFL and GALA are all more efficient than the naive method; 2) PackVFL is the most efficient over every matrix size; 3) with bigger m𝑚m and n𝑛n, PackVFL has a larger speedup over GALA, up to 1.24×1.24\times. This experiment indicates that our MatMult method is also more efficient than GALA in communication-insensitive cases. We can extend it to other areas, e.g., secure model inference (Mann et al., 2022).

8. Conclusion

In this paper, we accelerate the main-stream Paillier-based VFL algorithms with PackedHE, which provides a counter-intuitive speedup. The intuition of VFL researchers is that PackedHE tends to be less efficient than Paillier since PackedHE is more complicated and supports more cryptographic operations. However, this paper shows that PackedHE is more suitable for VFL tasks considering both efficiency and security.
